title: Takeshi Kamo
text:
was a Japanese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>. His brother <a href="Shogo%20Kamo">Shogo Kamo</a> also played for Japan national team.
National team career.
Kamo was born in <a href="Hamamatsu">Hamamatsu</a> on February 8, 1915. In 1936, when he was a <a href="Waseda%20University">Waseda University</a> student, he was selected <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> for <a href="Football%20at%20the%201936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>. At this competition, on August 4, he debuted against <a href="Sweden%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a>. Japan completed a come-from-behind victory against Sweden. The first victory in Olympics for the Japan and the historic victory over one of the powerhouses became later known as "Miracle of Berlin" () in Japan. In 2016, this team was selected <a href="Japan%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Japan Football Hall of Fame</a>. On August 7, he also played against <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a>. He played 2 games for Japan in 1936. His younger brother <a href="Shogo%20Kamo">Shogo Kamo</a> was also an Olympic footballer for Japan.
On March 26, 2004, Kamo died of <a href="heart%20failure">heart failure</a> at <a href="Miyamae-ku%2C%20Kawasaki">Miyamae</a> Hospital in <a href="Kawasaki%2C%20Kanagawa">Kawasaki</a> at the age of 89. He was the last surviving member of his team from the 1936 Olympics.
